	• More recent posture changes announced in 2012 are being assessed for their impact on the replacement medical center

	• However, DOD's documentation had inconsistencies in projecting workload, inadequate details on estimating requirements, and calculation errors

Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* ICE officers exercise discretion throughout the alien apprehension and removal process, particularly in the initial phases
	* Officers have more latitude when encountering aliens who are not investigation targets or have humanitarian issues
	* Guidance instructs officers to consider factors like flight risk, threat to community, and humanitarian issues when deciding to detain aliens
	* Officers can pursue alternatives to apprehension like mailing a Notice to Appear or scheduling a future appointment
* ICE has taken some steps to guide officer decision-making but guidance is not comprehensive
	* ICE updated some training to reflect expanded enforcement efforts but guidance in field manuals is outdated
	* Various ICE memos provide some instruction on discretion but are not comprehensive and only apply to certain officers
	* ICE lacks a mechanism to consistently disseminate legal developments to officers across all field offices
* ICE has controls to monitor removal operations but cannot analyze trends in discretionary decisions
	* Supervisory reviews and a new inspection program monitor compliance with policies and procedures
	* However, these do not allow analysis of data on discretionary decisions across field offices to identify trends
	* Databases do not capture details on discretionary decisions and ICE has not assessed costs and benefits of collecting this data
</summary>

Here is a summary of the source text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* Ground ambulance services are provided by a variety of organizations that differ in structure, staffing, types of transports, and revenue sources
	* Medicare pays ambulance providers through a national fee schedule with a service-level payment and a mileage payment
	* Providers' costs per transport in 2010 were highly variable, ranging from $224 to $2,204, with a median of $429
	* Personnel costs accounted for the largest percentage of providers' total costs in 2010
	* Providers with lower transport volumes generally had higher costs per transport than providers with greater volumes
* The median Medicare margin for providers in the sample was 2% in 2010 with add-on payments, but -1% without add-on payments
	* Ambulance transports for Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries increased by 33% from 2004 to 2010
	* The increase was primarily due to a 59% rise in BLS nonemergency transports
	* Increased billing by local governments and the introduction of the national fee schedule in 2002 may have contributed to the increase
	* The HHS OIG has cited improper payments as a potential cause of the increase in utilization
* The GAO provided a draft of the report to HHS and AAA for review
	* HHS had no comments on behalf of CMS
	* AAA generally agreed with the findings but had some questions about the methodology and conclusions
	* AAA noted that the sample represents mature, well-established providers and may not be representative of all providers
	* AAA questioned some of the regression analysis results and noted that current Medicare payments are lower than in 2010
* The GAO conducted the study from April to September 2012 using a survey of ambulance providers and analysis of Medicare claims data
	* The survey collected data on costs, revenues, transports, and organizational characteristics for 2010
	* The sample was drawn from a 2007 sample of providers that billed Medicare in 2003 and were still operational in 2012
	* Medicare claims data was used to calculate 2010 payments for providers in the sample and to examine ambulance utilization

Here is a summary of the text using 5 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• The military services have maintained accountability of SRC I ammunition at sampled locations, but there are gaps in some service-level guidance and procedures
	• The Air Force does not track SRC I ammunition by serial number but plans to revise guidance
	• Air Force procedures have not maintained accountability for items owned by other services
	• The services generally recorded shipment and receipt, but not always in a timely manner
• The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition
	• The Army has not ensured timely and complete information of items returned to the contractor
	• The Army inaccurately categorized two variants of SRC I rockets but took action to correct it
	• The services have not always entered timely, accurate, and complete data in the Defense Transportation Tracking System
• GAO made six recommendations to enhance DOD's policy, procedures, accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition
	• Revise Air Force guidance to maintain accountability of all SRC I items regardless of ownership
	• Finalize Army and Marine Corps guidance on required timeframes for receipting SRC I ammunition
	• Have the Army evaluate actions to retain accountability for in-transit items
• DOD concurred with all six recommendations and plans to implement them
	• The Air Force issued a memo directing units to account for all SRC I items regardless of ownership
	• The Army and Marine Corps will include receipting timeframe procedures in their guidance
	• The services will collaboratively determine information needed to improve DTTS data and tracking
• Previous GAO reports since 1994 have identified issues with DOD's management of SRC I ammunition
	• Weaknesses were found in serial number registration, physical inventories, and transportation
	• Most of the recommendations from these prior reports have been implemented by DOD
	• A few recommendations remain open, such as selecting an authoritative data source for ammunition
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• SSA maintains personal information on individuals to administer Social Security programs
	• SSA has a long history of protecting the confidentiality of this information
	• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and most federal agencies
	• SSA cites the personal nature of the information and its pledge of confidentiality as reasons
• SSA's disclosure policy allows sharing limited information with law enforcement under certain conditions
	• Information is generally limited to verification of name and SSN
	• More information may be provided for investigations involving SSA programs or serious crimes
	• All disclosures must meet specific criteria outlined in SSA's policy
• Some SSA field office staff are confused about the disclosure policy, leading to inconsistent application
	• Requests from law enforcement are infrequent, so staff must often consult the complex policy
	• SSA's responsibilities to assist law enforcement and protect privacy may exacerbate confusion
	• Consistent application cannot be fully assessed as SSA does not maintain aggregated disclosure data
• Most law enforcement officials were satisfied with information from SSA, but many wanted more
	• Name and SSN verification was often helpful, but many wanted additional details
	• Some state and local officials were unfamiliar with SSA's process for obtaining information
	• Many SSA field office and OIG staff agreed the policy was too restrictive
• SSA has concerns about expanding its disclosure policy
	• Officials believe it would hamper SSA's ability to protect privacy and administer programs
	• Balancing privacy and assisting law enforcement are important but sometimes conflicting objectives
	• SSA's complex policy attempts to uphold its privacy pledge while complying with applicable laws
• GAO recommends SSA take steps to ensure consistent policy application and inform law enforcement
	• Eliminate staff confusion through training, clarification, or delegating disclosure authority
	• Provide clear information to law enforcement on SSA's disclosure policy and procedures
	• SSA agreed to consider additional training and review public materials on its policy
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• RCRA establishes national policy for managing hazardous waste to minimize threats to health and environment
	• Governs hazardous waste from generation to disposal
	• Contains provisions for identifying and listing hazardous waste
• Three RCRA requirements cited as creating disincentives for cleanups
	• Land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements add cost and time
	• Can lead to cleanup remedies that are too stringent or not stringent enough
• Land disposal restrictions require waste to be treated to minimize threats before land disposal
	• Treatment to meet standards may be more stringent and costly than necessary for some waste
	• Can drive use of cleanup technologies more stringent and costly than needed to be protective
• Minimum technological requirements establish design and operating specifications for treatment/disposal facilities
	• Requirements designed for waste from ongoing operations may be too stringent for some remediation waste
	• Disposing of lower-risk remediation waste per requirements adds unnecessary costs
• Permit requirements involve substantial documentation and review, increasing costs and delays
	• Costs to obtain permit can range from $80,000 to $1 million
	• Process to obtain permit is lengthy, typically taking 5-6 years
• To avoid triggering RCRA requirements, parties may leave waste in place without treatment
	• Leaving waste in place, especially "old waste," may pose health or environmental risks
	• Contaminated land is not placed back into productive use
• EPA has modified RCRA's application to remediation waste through policy statements and regulatory alternatives
	• Alternatives have lessened but not solved adverse effects
	• States have varied experience using alternatives; some find them burdensome and overly complicated
• In 1996, EPA proposed new rules to more comprehensively reform RCRA's remediation waste requirements
	• Stakeholders disagree on technical and legal issues associated with proposed rule
	• EPA concluded comprehensive reform can best be addressed through legislation
• GAO recommends EPA take steps to ensure regulators have consistent understanding of alternatives
	• Steps could include consolidating alternatives into guidance, training managers, providing legal assistance
	• EPA agrees but notes benefits may be limited until comprehensive legislative reform achieved
</summary>

	* Beginning in 1997, Interior has issued several strategic plans for implementing trust reforms

	* In response to the firm's recommendations, the Secretary of the Interior reorganized BIA and the Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) in 2003
	* OST's budget and staff have grown significantly from 1997 to 2006 to support trust reform efforts and other Indian-related activities
* OST has implemented several key trust fund management reforms
	* However, OST has not prepared a timetable for completing its remaining trust reform activities
	* OST also has not identified a date for its termination under the 1994 American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act
* OST is responsible for trust reforms associated with the trust funds accounting system and the integration of trust reform automated systems
	* BIA and OST are responsible for reforms associated with the Trust Asset and Accounting Management System (TAAMS) for managing land title records and leasing activities
	* The National Business Center is responsible for developing an appraisal management system for Indian land appraisals
* OST managers plan to implement two additional trust reforms beyond those scheduled for completion by November 2007
	*

Here is a summary of the source text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* There are two approaches for reorganizing or terminating large financial companies:
	* Judicial bankruptcy process under Chapters 7 or 11 of the Bankruptcy Code
	* Special legal and regulatory resolution regimes for insured depository institutions and insurance companies
* The Bankruptcy Code provides for equitable treatment of creditors and allows business debtors to seek liquidation or reorganization
	* Regulators often play a role in financial company bankruptcies
	* Safe harbor provisions allow counterparties to exercise contractual rights for qualified financial contracts
* Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) under the Dodd-Frank Act allows FDIC to resolve large financial companies outside of bankruptcy
	* FDIC proposed a Single Point of Entry (SPOE) approach for resolving systemically important financial institutions
	* OLA uses a regulatory approach while bankruptcy reform bills maintain a judicial approach
* The resolution of globally active large financial firms faces complex international legal and operational challenges

	* Evaluations can isolate a program's impact from other factors to assess effectiveness
* GAO's 2013 survey found most federal managers lacked recent evaluations of their programs
	* Only about a third had recent evaluations, but most of those found the evaluations useful for understanding and improving performance
	* Lack of resources was the most commonly cited barrier to implementing evaluation findings
* GPRAMA aimed to increase the use of evidence in agency decision making
	* GPRAMA and OMB guidance established roles and processes to ensure the use of performance information
	* GPRAMA is part of a broader focus on using evidence to improve program effectiveness
* GAO's 2017 survey found no change since 2013 in managers' reported access to evaluations
	* 40% reported having evaluations, while 39% did not know if an evaluation had been conducted
	* Managers reported evaluations were used most to change program management or assess effectiveness, and least to allocate resources or inform the public
* Managers most frequently cited lack of resources as a barrier to using evaluation results
	* Other barriers were related to evaluation relevance, dissemination, and agency capacity
	* Managers infrequently reported congressional support or interest in evaluation as a barrier
* Managers most frequently cited leadership support, staff involvement, and relevance as facilitators of evaluation use
	* About a third cited each of these factors as greatly facilitating evaluation use
	* Fewer managers reported that performance reviews or stakeholder involvement facilitated use
* GAO recommends that OMB direct agencies to develop annual evaluation plans
	* Plans should describe key evaluation questions and stakeholders consulted
	* A more directive approach is needed given uneven improvement in evaluation capacity
</summary>

<summary>

	* NFIP is managed by FEMA and has been strengthened by subsequent legislation
* NFIP offers subsidized and full-risk premiums, but subsidized rates represent only 40-45% of the full risk cost
	* Despite mitigation efforts, repetitive loss properties and subsidized policies have continued to grow
* GAO has identified four goals for evaluating the federal role in providing natural catastrophe insurance
	* Goals include risk-based premiums, limiting taxpayer costs, encouraging broad participation, and encouraging private markets
* Increasing premium rates to reflect full risk of loss would have several advantages
	* However, it would also increase costs for some homeowners who might then cancel or not buy flood policies
* NFIP needs to generate sufficient premiums to pay claims, even in years with catastrophic losses
	* NFIP has borrowed from the Treasury to cover shortfalls, exposing taxpayers to risk of loss
* Increasing mitigation efforts could reduce flood damage and put NFIP on firmer financial footing
	* However, mitigation imposes upfront costs and FEMA has limited ability to compel mitigation of repetitive loss properties
* Increasing participation in NFIP would help spread risk and potentially reduce premium rates
	* However, NFIP is required to take all applicants and expansion would need to be implemented carefully
* Encouraging private market participation could transfer some risk exposure away from taxpayers
	* However, it could lead to higher premium rates and affordability concerns for low-income policyholders
* NFIP faces additional operational and management challenges that threaten the program's effectiveness and stability
	* Issues include strategic planning, financial controls, oversight, and information technology systems
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• User fees can help assign costs to readily identifiable users of federal programs
	• Fees represent a charge for a service or benefit received from a government program
	• Payers expect a link between payments and cost/quality of the related service
• The beneficiary-pays principle suggests costs should be assigned based on benefits
	• If a program primarily benefits the public, it should be supported by general revenue
	• If a program primarily benefits users, it should be funded by fees
• Setting fee rates requires determining program costs and assigning costs among users
	• Fees can be set using average cost or marginal cost
	• User-specific fees vs. systemwide fees involve trade-offs between efficiency and admin costs
• Striking a balance between compliance and administrative costs is key when collecting fees
	• Point-of-sale/service collection decreases admin costs but may not ensure compliance
	• Billing users adds admin costs but may be necessary in some cases
• Congress determines agency access to fee collections, balancing oversight and flexibility
	• Annual appropriations of fee collections allow regular Congressional oversight
	• Permanent or direct access to collections gives agencies more flexibility to respond to needs
• Regular fee reviews and stakeholder input improve transparency and acceptance of fees
	• Reviews help ensure fees remain aligned with program costs and activities
	• Stakeholder input is important since government is often a monopoly supplier of services
</summary>

	* Federal agencies must consult with FWS or NMFS to determine if projects jeopardize listed species or critical habitat

	* Only 6 exemptions have been sought and 2 granted in over 40 years
* The Endangered Species Committee (ESC) reviews exemption applications and makes the ultimate decision
	* The ESC is composed of cabinet-level officials and representatives from affected states
* Exemption applications are limited to the federal action agency, state governor, or permit/license applicant
	* Applicants must show they have met certain requirements before an exemption can be considered
* The Secretary of the Interior conducts a formal hearing and prepares a report for the ESC
	* The ESC must make specific determinations to grant an exemption based on the report and other evidence
* If an exemption is granted, the ESC must specify mitigation measures that the applicant is responsible for funding
	* Exemptions are permanent unless the Secretary later finds it would result in extinction of a species
* Exemptions apply to specific agency actions, not species, so FWS/NMFS must still work to recover the species
	* Conservation burden may fall more heavily on remaining habitat/resources after an exemption
* Practical and political challenges make the exemption process difficult and explain its rare use
	* Applicants must weigh costs of the process and mitigation against benefits of an exemption
* The ESA tends to force decisions on contentious land/water use issues, but the exemption process is rarely used
	* Consultation process allows for project modifications to avoid jeopardy and the need for exemptions
* Past exemption attempts illustrate the complexity and rarity of the process (Tellico Dam, Grayrocks Dam, BLM timber sales)
	* Some attempts were withdrawn or abandoned before completion (Pittston refinery, Mound City docking area, Suwanee Sound dredging)
</summary>

* The $3,000 loss limit prevents selective realization of losses from being a significant problem
	* Individuals can achieve tax benefits by realizing losses and holding assets with gains
	* The problem is exacerbated by the current asymmetrical treatment of capital gains and losses
	* Long-term gains are taxed at a maximum 15% rate while losses are deductible at up to 35%
	* Increasing the loss deduction would increase rewards for gaming the system
* Capital gains and losses are heavily concentrated in upper income ranges
	* Taxpayers in middle income ranges tend to hold gains-producing assets in tax-favored plans
	* Assets in retirement plans are not affected by the net loss restrictions
	* Benefits of increasing the loss deduction would accrue mainly to upper income taxpayers
* It is unclear if increasing the loss deduction would stimulate the economy
	* Measures to stimulate should focus on spending or tax cuts likely to be spent
	* An expanded loss deduction has a tenuous connection to expanded spending
	* It might increase sales of poorly performing stocks and depress markets further
* Historically, Congress has repeatedly changed the tax treatment of capital gains and losses
	* Between 1913-1916, losses were only deductible if associated with a trade or business
	* From 1916-1918, losses were deductible up to the amount of gains
	* From 1918-1921, losses in excess of gains were deductible against ordinary income
* The Revenue Act of 1921 significantly changed the treatment of gains and losses
	* It divided assets into short-term and long-term categories
	* It created an asymmetrical treatment of long-term gains and losses

• The number and percentage of taxpayers subject to AMT has increased dramatically and is projected to continue growing rapidly
	• In 1987, about 140,000 returns (0.1%) paid AMT; by 2009, over 9 million (6.3%) are projected to pay AMT
	• AMT will increasingly affect middle and upper-middle income taxpayers, not just the highest earners
• Fixing the AMT is costly - indexing exemptions and eliminating credit limits would cost tens of billions per year
	• Interaction with tax credits adopted in 1997 causes millions more to be affected by AMT
	• Any tax cuts that reduce regular tax without changing AMT will further increase AMT coverage and costs
• Marriage penalty relief provisions in tax cut bills can be substantially limited by the AMT
	• AMT will "take back" an increasing share of marriage penalty tax cuts over time if not adjusted

Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• U.S. imports of milk protein concentrates (MPCs) have limited trade restrictions compared to other dairy products
	• MPCs are derived from raw milk and used in various food, animal feed, and industrial products
	• Advocates of stricter MPC import controls say it would encourage domestic protein use and raise milk prices for farmers
	• Opponents argue it would increase costs and retail food prices, and major MPC suppliers would likely seek WTO compensation
	• MPC imports rose sharply in the late 1990s but have remained at or below 2000 peak levels since 2001
• Milk composition and protein types
	• Milk is 87.4% water and 12.6% milk solids (fat, protein, lactose, minerals)
	• Milk protein is casein (82% of protein) and whey protein (18% of protein)
	• Casein is used in foods and industrial applications; whey protein is used in various food products
	• MPCs contain casein and whey protein and are identified by protein percentage (e.g. MPC42 has 42% protein)
• U.S. dairy product imports and proposed legislation
	• The U.S. produces little casein or MPCs; federal dairy policies may have encouraged nonfat dry milk production instead
	• In 2008, cheese was the largest U.S. dairy import (38%) followed by MPCs and casein/caseinates combined (35%)
	• Proposed legislation (S. 1542, H.R. 3674) would introduce tariff-rate quotas on MPC and casein/caseinate imports
	• If enacted, the U.S. would likely need to negotiate compensation with major MPC supplier countries under WTO rules
• Potential impact of import restrictions
	• Dairy farmers generally support MPC import restrictions to close a "loophole" and improve farm-level prices
	• Dairy processors oppose restrictions, arguing it would increase costs, consumer prices, and jeopardize export gains
	• Impact depends on farm prices relative to government support levels; above-quota imports equate to ~0.7% of U.S. milk production

<summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases in its October 2012 term
	* Florida v. Jardines: A trained drug-sniffing dog's sniff at the front door of a suspected marijuana grow house is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause
	* Florida v. Harris: An alert by a well-trained narcotics-detection dog certified to detect illegal contraband is sufficient to establish probable cause to search a vehicle
* In Bailey v. United States, the Court held that under the Summers rule, the detention of an individual who has just left premises to be searched under warrant is only permissible in the immediate vicinity of the premises
	* The Court disagreed with the Second Circuit's extension of the Summers rule to allow off-site detention incident to the execution of a search warrant under certain conditions
	* The majority emphasized the narrow scope of the Summers rule exception to the Fourth Amendment's limits on personal liberty intrusions
* Missouri v. McNeely addressed whether the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream presents a per se exigency justifying a warrant exception for nonconsensual blood testing in drunk-driving cases
	* The Court rejected a per se exception, holding that the existence of exigent circumstances must be determined on a case-by-case basis considering the totality of the circumstances
	* The majority reaffirmed that the general rule requiring a warrant for searches involving bodily intrusions is particularly compelling, with exceptions only in certain emergency situations
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) of 1936 prohibits price discrimination between different purchasers of commodities of like grade and quality
	* Enacted to enable small businesses to compete with larger rivals
	* Prohibits sellers from charging different prices to different buyers of similar goods
	* Applies only to sale of goods, not services, purchased for resale in the U.S.
	* Department of Justice views the act as not beneficial to consumers
* Affirmative defenses permitted to refute illegality of differential pricing under R-P
	* Price differential made to meet competition of a competing seller
	* Price differential made to enable a buyer to meet competition
	* Price differentials that are cost-justified based on production/delivery costs
	* Nonprofit Institutions Act exemption for supplies purchased for own use
* Supreme Court interpretations of the scope of the nonprofit exemption
	* Abbott Laboratories v. Portland Retail Druggists (1976): exemption limited to purchases for hospital's own needs
	* Jefferson County v. Abbott Laboratories (1983): purchases for retail competition subject to R-P
	* De Modena v. Kaiser (1984): health maintenance organizations eligible for exemption
	* Exemption for HMOs providing complete health care to members not judicially repudiated
* Proving price discrimination and damages
	* If defenses and exemptions unavailable, price discrimination is proved
	* Damages not automatic; plaintiff must show actual injury (J.Truett Payne v. Chrysler)
	* Previously split lower courts on automatic damages theory
	* More persuasive opinions rejected automatic damages
* Efforts to amend or repeal the Robinson-Patman Act
	* 1970s hearings held; small business contended R-P was essential
	* No legislation introduced despite draft bills from DOJ
	* Antitrust Modernization Commission (2007) recommended repeal
	* Unintended effect of R-P was to limit discounting and raise consumer prices
* Current status and potential future actions unknown
	* Economic climate may renew efforts to modify or repeal R-P
	*

Here is a summary of the source document using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* The Obama administration has faced scrutiny for limiting enforcement of certain federal laws based on policy considerations rather than constitutional concerns
	* Nonenforcement decisions have been justified as an exercise of enforcement discretion, which generally shields executive enforcement decisions from judicial review
* Prosecutorial discretion in the criminal context and administrative enforcement discretion in civil/administrative contexts are two distinct forms of enforcement discretion
	* The DOJ has cited prosecutorial discretion in limiting enforcement of federal marijuana laws in states that have legalized medical or recreational marijuana
* The Take Care Clause of the Constitution has been interpreted as both imposing a duty on the President to enforce laws and ensuring presidential control over law enforcement
	* Once a law is enacted, the President has an obligation to "take care" that it is faithfully executed and may not disregard or suspend the law
* Courts have been reluctant to review executive discretionary enforcement decisions, both in criminal prosecutions and administrative actions
	* Such decisions are generally "committed to agency discretion" and not subject to judicial review under the Administrative Procedure Act
* Congress may override executive enforcement discretion by providing explicit statutory guidelines or meaningful standards on how the executive must enforce a law
	* Mandatory language (e.g. "shall enforce") without additional direction is likely insufficient to allow judicial review of nonenforcement
* General nonenforcement policies are more likely to be subject to judicial review compared to individual, case-by-case enforcement decisions
	* Policies that amount to an abdication of statutory responsibilities may be reviewable
* The precise scope of Congress's authority to limit executive enforcement discretion remains unsettled, but there are likely some constitutional limits on legislative control over enforcement
	* Congress likely cannot itself enforce the law, remove the President's control over enforcement, or direct the executive to prosecute a specific individual
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* Poverty in the U.S. has fluctuated over time, tending to rise during economic recessions and fall during periods of growth
	* The official poverty rate was 14.5% in 2013, down from 15.0% in 2012, marking the first significant drop since 2006
	* Poverty rates are highest among minorities, women and children, the elderly, the unemployed, and those with lower education levels
	* Poverty is more concentrated in central cities and in the South, with wide variation in rates among states and metropolitan areas
	* Government programs like Social Security, EITC, SNAP, and housing subsidies have helped reduce poverty, especially among the elderly and children
* The Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) was developed to address weaknesses in the official poverty measure
	* The SPM accounts for in-kind benefits, taxes, and necessary expenses like child care and medical costs that the official measure ignores
	* Under the SPM in 2013, the overall poverty rate was 15.5%, higher than the 14.6% rate under the adjusted official measure
	* The SPM shows lower poverty among children but much higher poverty among the elderly compared to the official measure
	* Geographic adjustments in the SPM result in higher poverty rates in the Northeast and West where housing costs are high
* The SPM provides additional insights into the effects of government policies and programs on poverty
	* Benefits like the EITC, SNAP, and housing subsidies have a significant impact on reducing poverty under the SPM
	* Necessary expenses like work-related costs, payroll taxes, and medical out-of-pocket costs contribute to higher poverty under the SPM
	* The SPM captures the policy effects of in-kind benefits and also expands the definition of economic units to include cohabiting partners
	* As a research measure, the SPM offers the potential to better understand the circumstances of the most economically vulnerable populations
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* The U.S. is a major agricultural producer and exporter, and its farm policies are subject to WTO rules and limits on domestic support spending that distorts trade
	* The Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) categorizes and restricts agricultural domestic support programs based on their potential to distort markets
	* Programs are classified as green box (minimal distortion), blue box (production-limiting), or amber box (most distorting and subject to spending limits)
	* The U.S. is also subject to the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM) for domestic support that results in adverse effects on other WTO members
* U.S. farm bill programs must comply with WTO rules to avoid potential challenges and trade disputes
	* Amber box spending is limited to $19.1 billion annually, with exemptions for blue box, green box, and de minimis (minimal) spending
	* A program that is AoA-compliant could still be challenged under the SCM if it distorts trade and adversely impacts other WTO members
	* The 2014 farm bill includes a provision for USDA to adjust program outlays if needed to avoid exceeding the amber box limit
* In its 2012 notification to the WTO, the U.S. reported domestic support spending as:
	* $127.5 billion in green box outlays including general services, domestic food aid, decoupled income support, and conservation programs
	* $5.3 billion in de minimis exclusions for programs with minimal trade impacts
	* $6.9 billion in amber box support subject to the $19.1 billion limit, including commodity-specific crop insurance, dairy and sugar price support, and some non-product specific support
</summary>

Here is a summary of the source text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods for the President to appoint officers: with Senate advice and consent, or unilaterally during a Senate recess
	* President Obama had difficulty getting Senate confirmation for nominees to the CFPB and NLRB
	* In January 2012, Obama made recess appointments to these positions during pro forma Senate sessions
	* These recess appointments have been controversial and raise significant legal questions
* Whether a court will reach the merits of a legal challenge to the appointments depends on the justiciability doctrines of standing and the political question doctrine
	* Private individuals impacted by CFPB or NLRB actions likely have standing to sue
	* Member of Congress plaintiffs would face a rigorous standing inquiry
	* Some issues, like determining the length of a recess, may be political questions that courts decline to answer
* Key questions in assessing the constitutionality of the recess appointments are whether pro forma sessions interrupt a recess and if a recess must be a minimum length
	* If pro forma sessions are meaningful, the appointments occurred during a 3-day recess; if not, it was a 20-day recess
	* Historically, no President has made an intrasession recess appointment during a recess of less than 10 days
	* The Constitution does not specify a minimum recess length, but the Adjournment Clause's 3-day rule might be relevant
* If the appointments are constitutional, a court may need to interpret the CFPB statute to determine a recess-appointed director's authorities
	* One interpretation gives a recess-appointed director like Cordray full authority under the statute
	* Another interpretation suggests Cordray can only exercise certain authorities, while others remain with the Treasury Secretary
	* The latter interpretation may raise constitutional concerns by limiting a recess appointee's powers
</summary>

	* The Senate proposed $1,346 million, a 5.2% decrease from the request

	* Included $405 million (35.5%) more than FY2015

	* The Senate proposed $263 million, 2.1% below the request

Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• Gross job loss is a normal part of a functioning market economy, while net job loss is an economic problem
	• Gross job loss occurs even during economic expansions but is offset by greater gross job gains
	• Net job loss is typically only persistent during and after recessions
• Trade, outsourcing, overseas investment, and economic restructuring cause gross job loss but not net job loss
	• These factors reallocate resources to more efficient uses, similar to technological advances
	• Evidence shows countries with barriers to job loss tend to have lower job gains and higher unemployment
• Policies to protect workers from risks of gross job loss can be justified on social and economic grounds
	• Properly designed policies can address market failures without reducing job gains
	• Public unemployment insurance helps overcome moral hazard and adverse selection problems
• Policymakers must balance mitigating risks for workers with maintaining labor market dynamism
	• Fiscal and monetary policy can be used to mitigate serious net job losses
	• The goal is to find the right level of worker protection in an increasingly fluid labor market
</summary>

* The U.S.-Japan alliance remains strong, though trade frictions have increased under the Trump administration
	* The U.S. and Japan have strengthened defense cooperation in recent years, including Japan's 2014 reinterpretation of its constitution to allow collective self-defense
	* President Trump has criticized Japan on trade and burden-sharing, and withdrew the U.S. from the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement, which Japan has continued to pursue
* Japan's economy has experienced slow growth for decades since the collapse of an asset price bubble in the early 1990s
	* Abe has pursued an ambitious economic agenda called "Abenomics" to combat deflation and spur growth, with mixed results so far
	* Structural reforms, including in the labor market and corporate sector, remain a challenge for generating sustainable long-term growth
* The U.S. and Japan are pursuing bilateral trade agreement negotiations, which Japan agreed to in part to avoid potential U.S. tariffs on auto imports
	* The Trump administration has already imposed tariffs on Japanese steel and aluminum exports and is considering additional tariffs on autos
	* The scope of the bilateral trade talks remains unclear, but Japan has said it will not open its agriculture market beyond its prior commitments in the Trans-Pacific Partnership
* The U.S. maintains about 50,000 military personnel in Japan and has sought greater contributions from Japan to support the alliance
	* Japan pays nearly $2 billion per year to defray the cost of stationing U.S. forces, but calculating the percentage of overall U.S. costs covered by Japan is difficult
	* The relocation of the Futenma base in Okinawa remains a challenging issue in the alliance, with strong local opposition in Okinawa to the construction of a replacement facility

	• The act's central policy contributions were the "doubling path" policy for the NSF, NIST, and DOE Office of Science, and authorization of STEM education activities.

	• Of the new programs authorized in COMPETES 2010, only the Regional Innovation Program at the Department of Commerce was included in the budget request.
• Congressional appropriations for COMPETES 2010-related agencies in FY2013 were provided through two acts: a continuing resolution through March 2013 (P.L. 112-175) and a consolidated appropriations act for the rest of FY2013 (P.L. 113-6).

• The COMPETES acts aimed to improve U.S. competitiveness by increasing funding for physical sciences and engineering research and STEM education, but this approach has faced some opposition over fundamental assumptions, preferences for alternative policies, and concerns about costs.

</summary>

Here is a summary of the discussion about why children on free school meals were less resilient in the exam system last year:

<summary>
• There is no one single reason why free school meal children were less resilient in exams last year
	• Possible factors include the move from BTECs to science GCSEs and the impact of studying literature
	• The Cabinet Secretary will have a deep dive discussion on this topic at the next ministerial policy board in May
	• Officials are working with Qualifications Wales to better understand the issue
• While the overall gap widened in 2017, there has been a narrowing of the gap over the period that PDG has been employed
	• In 2009, 1 in 5 free school meal children got Level 2 plus, improving to 1 in 3 by 2016
	• Some schools saw improved free school meal performance in 2017 compared to 2016
	• Need to understand what enabled free school meal children to do well in certain schools
• The Cabinet Secretary emphasized that broad conclusions cannot be drawn and school-level factors are important
	• Large variations in free school meal performance can be seen even between similar schools in the same local authority
	• One school in Swansea had free school meal Level 2 performance of 88% while another similar school was in the 20% range
	• The challenge is to go into individual schools and understand what led to their children doing well or not
• The government is moving away from using Level 2 plus as the main performance measure
	• A new, more sophisticated performance measure looking at individual pupil progress will be announced soon
	• Level 2 plus is seen as too narrow and has driven unintended behaviors in schools
	• Value added by schools in pupil performance will be a key part of the new measure
</summary>

Here is a summary of the key points from the discussion:

<summary>
• Professor C announces that Hans-Guenter will be visiting for 3 weeks to collaborate and provide input on their research
	• He is very knowledgeable and easy to talk to
	• The grad students should plan to discuss their work with him
• Sunil presents results on using Wiener filtering for noise reduction
	• A single stage Wiener filter gives a 30% improvement over the MFCC baseline
	• Using a second stage of Wiener filtering with smoothing improves performance to 56.5% over baseline
	• Using the channel 0 VAD endpoints further improves performance to 67% over baseline, showing the importance of good VAD
• Stephane presents results on using spectral subtraction for noise reduction 
	• Subtracting more at low SNRs by overestimating the noise does not improve performance alone
	• Applying nonlinear smoothing of the spectral subtraction gain helps, giving slightly better results than Wiener filtering on Italian data
	• The smoothing helps reduce musical noise artifacts
• They discuss how spectral subtraction can lead to negative spectrum values which are typically thresholded or filled in
	• Leaving the negatives or not subtracting those bins are alternative approaches to consider
	• Musical noise may sound bad but it's unclear if it actually hurts recognition performance
• The France Telecom system uses a variant of Wiener filtering with both time and frequency domain smoothing
	• Stephane's and Sunil's approaches are conceptually similar with multiple stages of noise reduction and smoothing
	• They are evaluating multiple techniques like Wiener filtering, spectral subtraction, and subspace methods to determine what works best
</summary>

<summary>
• The Professor discussed the Aurora project and competition between different groups
	• French Telecom Alcatel and the Professor's group both had voice activity detectors, which was seen as unfair by other groups

	• French Telecom was concerned other groups would copy their code if a new evaluation was done
	• The Professor's group was willing to share their code and techniques
• There was debate over the criteria and weighting for the Aurora evaluation
	• Some groups wanted to lower the improvement threshold from 50% to 25% for mismatched conditions
	• The Professor thought this was a major decision being made too lightly and that they should try to reach 50% again
	• Nokia and Qualcomm supported keeping the 50% threshold
	• The Professor thought some groups were trying to match the criteria to their existing solution rather than improve the technology
• The Professor's group at OGI was working on improving their system, especially noise separation
	• They were looking at using the LPC spectrum instead of FFT to be more robust to noise
	• They considered techniques like spectral subtraction and adding noise to all data to make any additive noise less effective
	• Most of their effort was on a new recognition approach using temporal patterns (TRAPs)
• Stephane observed that the C1 cepstral coefficient was not very useful in their system
	• Removing C1 had little effect on performance
	• This led to a discussion on how to adjust the importance of different coefficients by modifying the model variances
	• Increasing variance would decrease importance of a coefficient; decreasing variance would increase importance
• The Professor shared anecdotes highlighting inefficiencies and lack of oversight in some organizations
	• One company had an employee hitting carriage returns to inflate billable computer usage time
	• Soldiers manning a lookout post outsourced their one daily task of reporting a passing plane to a pub owner
</summary>

Here is a summary of the discussion using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• The Deputy Minister responded to concerns that nearly 70% of individuals who responded to the consultation do not support the bill to ban physical punishment of children
	• She said the bill aims to prohibit all forms of physical punishment to protect children's rights, not address child abuse
	• She acknowledged people have different views but believes the law should not defend physical punishment of children
• The Deputy Minister was asked how the government will work with parents who consider physical punishment part of their parenting toolkit given limited resources
	• She said bringing up children is hard but there are many alternative methods to physical punishment
	• She pointed to support from professionals and representative surveys for the bill's principles
• Concerns were raised about statistics from Sweden showing increased child-on-child violence after banning physical punishment
	• The Deputy Minister said evidence is mixed, with a large cross-national study of 88 countries showing less youth violence when corporal punishment is prohibited
	• She said the decision is based on a commitment to children's rights
• It was noted the bill's explanatory memorandum says there is no definitive evidence that reasonable physical punishment causes negative outcomes, contrary to some views
	• The Deputy Minister said they commissioned balanced independent research showing all physical punishment is potentially harmful
	• She said there is no peer-reviewed research showing physically punishing a child has favorable outcomes
• Concerns were raised about how agencies will address malicious reporting and whether the public interest test will be applied appropriately
	• The Deputy Minister said an implementation group with key stakeholders is working on addressing many of these issues
	• She is confident the legislation will be implemented in a practical and workable way with the commitment of agencies
• Questions were asked about whether social services may change their thresholds for intervention if more cases are referred to them
	• The Deputy Minister said social services already investigate reports of physical punishment and use standard procedures
	• She does not expect the threshold of significant harm to change based on evidence from the Association of Directors of Social Services Cymru
• The need for consistently effective multi-agency safeguarding hubs across the country was discussed
	• The Deputy Minister said effective implementation does not depend on MASHs as social services already work closely with police
	• She said other joint working mechanisms are in place but MASH

Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• The group discussed the need for clarity in the law regarding physical punishment of children
	• Current law is unclear and ineffective in protecting children's rights
	• Physical punishment is harmful to children based on their own views and social services' experience
	• Reasonable punishment defense undermines child protection and can lead to more serious abuse
	• Greater clarity is needed in the definition of corporal punishment
• The group emphasized the importance of awareness raising and support for parents if the law changes
	• Local authorities have been working with the Welsh Government on implementation plans
	• Additional resources will be needed to support prevention and early intervention services for families
	• Schools will play a key role in discussing the issues with children and supporting families
	• Some unintended positive consequences could be increased focus on children's rights and their voices
• The group does not anticipate a major impact on social services' capacity to implement the law
	• Thresholds for intervention are not expected to change significantly
	• Most referrals will likely require no action after initial assessment
	• Prevention and support services will be offered to families when concerns are identified
	• Emergency and out-of-hours services have been considered as part of implementation planning
• The group is confident that education professionals will be clear on their duties to report suspected harm
	• Existing training and guidance for safeguarding will be updated
	• The duty to report will remain paramount, with social services determining thresholds
	• Trust between professionals and families is important and consent is sought for most referrals
	• Family support officers in schools are critical in engaging with families
• The group believes clearly communicating that the law is not meant to criminalize parents is crucial
	• A broad awareness campaign using various avenues will be needed
	• The numbers of parents prosecuted is expected to be very small
	• Placing a duty on ministers to raise awareness, as in Scotland, should be considered
	• The Welsh Government has committed to an awareness campaign if the law passes
• The group argues that the costs of implementing the law are justified to protect children's rights
	• Costs will be spread across training, awareness, and some potential increase in referrals
	• Much of the training aligns with existing programs on child protection and adverse childhood experiences

Here is a summary of the meeting discussion using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* Discussed agenda items including NSF ITR proposal, digits, and naming conventions
	* Professor A provided an update on the NSF ITR pre-proposal
	* Grad B discussed issues with digits that were misread and how to handle them
	* Grad B brought up naming conventions for sound files to make sorting easier
* Discussed progress on transcriptions and challenges encountered
	* Postdoc F switched to doing channel-by-channel transcriptions
	* Discovered issues like time lags and overlooked backchannels during dense overlaps
	* Considering having transcribers focus on single channels and piecing together later
* PhD C provided an update on his work with harmonicity detection
	* Trying to improve the harmonicity detector and distinguish between harmonic and non-harmonic frequency peaks
	* Discussed different approaches like using energy ratios and instantaneous frequency
	* Plans to prepare results and have further discussions to understand the issues
* Discussed the NSF ITR proposal and its potential impact on ICSI
	* If awarded, it would extend research beyond current Meeting Recorder work to higher-level issues
	* Would require hiring new students and expanding the team at ICSI and UW
	* Proposal is due in about a month, with a lot of the work being done by others besides Professor A
* Discussed how to handle breaths in the transcriptions
	* Question raised about whether breaths are needed for speech recognition research
	* Argument made to keep breaths as they are part of real speech data
	* Considered ways to more efficiently annotate breaths, such as using a breath detector
* Discussed the contrast between needs for speech recognition vs. discourse research
	* Discourse research focuses on what is communicative, while speech recognition needs to handle all real phenomena
	* Plan to have a master transcript with everything, and scripts to extract subsets for different uses
	* Looking for ways to efficiently annotate breaths, such as only within transcribed segments
</summary>

Here is a summary of the key points from the meeting:

<summary>
* The group discussed results from testing their speech recognition system on the Aurora dataset in different languages and noise conditions
	* The system showed improvements of 30-60% error rate reduction compared to the baseline
	* However, even with these improvements, the error rates are still too high (8-9% per digit) for practical use in real applications
* They compared their results to other top performing systems and discussed ideas for further improving performance
	* Combining the best aspects of different systems, such as spectral subtraction, cepstral normalization, and the group's modulation filtering, could yield even better results
	* More analysis is needed to understand the sources of errors, such as confusion between phoneme classes in noisy conditions
* The group brainstormed additional experiments and directions to explore going forward
	* Taking a closer look at the realistic noise conditions in the Aurora and in-house datasets
	* Revisiting ideas that didn't work well initially, such as articulatory features, MSG, and multi-band processing
	* Training multiple neural networks on data from different acoustic conditions or languages
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• Transport properties of nonlinear non-equilibrium dynamical systems are not well-understood
	• Ratchet systems are asymmetric periodic potentials where particles experience directed transport
• Chaotic deterministic ratchets have complicated phase-space structure that changes with parameters
	• Transport properties can change dramatically, such as current reversals
• Mateos conjectured current reversal is correlated with bifurcation from chaotic to periodic behavior
	• Later studies by Barbi and Salerno argued this is not always valid
• The authors study current properties in the same chaotic ratchet system
	• They consider the impact of different particle ensembles and show current depends on initial ensemble
• Bifurcations for individual trajectories seem associated with abrupt changes in current
	• Changes may lead to current reversal depending on the specific current value
• The authors compare bifurcation diagrams with current behavior
	• They find current reversals can occur without bifurcations, and vice versa
• A generalized heuristic is proposed: bifurcations correspond to sudden current changes (spikes/jumps)
	• Current reversals are a special case of this when the change goes through zero
• Open questions remain about when the heuristic rules are violated or valid
	• Further work is needed to make the reasons more concrete
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 1 level of sub-points:

<summary>
* Many extrasolar planets have moderate to high eccentricities, unlike our solar system
	* Planet-planet scattering and interactions with stellar companions are possible explanations
* Six highly eccentric extrasolar planetary systems were studied: HD 3651, HD 37605, HD 45350, HD 80606, HD 89744, and 16 Cyg B
	* Each hosts a planet with e > 0.6 and was observed by planet search programs at McDonald Observatory
* Updated Keplerian orbital solutions were obtained for HD 3651b, HD 37605b, HD 80606b, and HD 89744b
	* No evidence was found for additional objects in any of the six systems
* Test particle simulations were performed to investigate regions where additional low-mass planets could remain stable
	* Surviving test particles were found in protected resonances for HD 3651 and HD 37605
* Limits on additional planets were computed using the radial velocity data
	* Planets with masses above the limits can be ruled out with 99% confidence
* The best limits were obtained for HD 3651, HD 45350, and 16 Cyg B
	* Planets of a few Neptune masses can be excluded in dynamically stable regions for these systems
* Poor limits were obtained for HD 37605, HD 80606, and HD 89744
	* Factors include poor phase coverage, short time baselines, and intrinsic scatter in the data
* Combining dynamical simulations with observational limits is particularly effective
	* This approach constrains both the presence and location of additional planets
* Further observations and simulations can place tighter constraints on planetary system architectures
	* Higher precision measurements and longer time baselines will continue to improve detection limits
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• Rare Z-boson decays are studied in the Type-II 2HDM, Lepton-specific 2HDM, NMSSM and nMSSM models, which predict a light CP-odd Higgs boson A0
	• Decays studied include Z → f𝑓A0 (f = b, τ, μ), Z → A0γ and Z → A0A0A0
	• Branching ratios can reach 10−5 for Z → 𝑏𝑏A0, 10−8 for Z → A0γ and 10−6 for Z → A0A0A0 in allowed parameter space
	• Different models predict different branching ratios, allowing them to be distinguished
• The light CP-odd Higgs A0 in NMSSM and nMSSM is mostly singlet, suppressing its couplings to SM fermions
	• Main decay modes are 𝑏𝑏 (dominant) and ττ (subdominant) for Type-II 2HDM, NMSSM and nMSSM
	• For L2HDM, main decay mode is ττ
	• In rare cases, neutralino pairs are possible decay products in NMSSM
• Constraints on the models come from theoretical considerations, collider searches, precision electroweak data, muon g-2, b-physics observables and dark matter relic density
	• tan β is constrained differently in the various models based on these constraints
	• NMSSM and nMSSM also have constraints on SUSY particle masses and couplings
• Random scans of the parameter spaces of the four models were performed, taking into account all relevant constraints
	• About 5000 surviving points in each scan satisfy mA0 < 90 GeV

<summary>
* Colliding plane waves (CPW) result in spacelike singularities, but cross polarization or electromagnetic (EM) fields can weaken the singularities
    * The Chandrasekhar-Xanthopoulos (CX) solution has a Cauchy horizon (CH) instead of a spacelike singularity

    * EM fields coupled to gravity result in weaker singularities compared to pure gravitational waves
* The Bell-Szekeres (BS) solution describes the collision of two linearly polarized step EM waves
    * The singularity in the interaction region of the BS solution is a removable CH
    * The cross-polarized version of the BS (CPBS) solution has regular Weyl scalars in the interaction region
    * The CPBS solution is used to test the validity of the Helliwell-Konkowski (HK) CH stability conjecture
* Test fields are added to the CPBS background to study the stability of quasi-regular (QR) singularities
    * Test EM fields predict the QR singularities are unstable and transform into non-scalar curvature singularities
    * Test scalar fields also predict the QR singularities are unstable and transform into scalar curvature singularities
    * Exact back-reaction solutions are presented for the collision of cross-polarized EM fields coupled with scalar fields
* The stability of QR singularities in the CPBS spacetime is analyzed using test EM fields, scalar fields, and null dust
    * Test EM fields indicate the QR singularities become non-scalar curvature singularities
    * Test scalar fields predict the QR singularities transform into scalar curvature singularities, confirmed by an exact back-reaction solution
    * Test null dust results in the CH becoming a scalar curvature singularity, as predicted by the conjecture and confirmed by an exact back-reaction solution
* The paper concludes that the HK stability conjecture correctly predicts the instability of QR

• FeII emission is ubiquitous in type 1 quasars and is thought to arise from the same region as other low ionization lines like Hβ
	• A recent study by Hu et al. (2008) claimed a systematic redshift of FeII emission relative to [OIII] in most type 1 quasars, with the redshift amplitude inversely correlating with Eddington ratio
• The authors tested this claim using composite spectra of bright SDSS quasars binned by Hβ FWHM and FeII strength, finding no significant FeII redshift relative to Hβ or [OIII]
	• Fits to composites generated from the Hu et al. (2008) sample also do not confirm the large claimed FeII redshifts, with only small possible redshifts of <300 km/s for population A sources
• The discrepancy is likely due to the lower S/N of the Hu et al. spectra and their omission of HeII λ4686 emission in the fits, which can mimic an apparent redshift of the FeII blue blend
	• Careful analysis of high S/N spectra is needed to reliably detect small systematic FeII shifts, but large shifts are not confirmed
• The results challenge the idea that FeII emission arises from a dynamically distinct region from Hβ and the use of FeII shifts as an orientation indicator
	• Small systematic FeII shifts are possible but can only be analyzed reliably in high S/N spectra
</summary>

	* The system consists of the coronagraph, SECIS (two fast-frame CCD cameras), and an opto-mechanical interface
* The optical system was designed to avoid vignetting, limit aberrations, and ensure equal exposure times in narrow-band and broad-band channels
	* The system is mounted in a rigid, light-tight box and requires minimal alignment at the telescope
* SECIS has been successfully used during total solar eclipses and for high time resolution spectral observations of solar flares
	* Preliminary tests of the entire system were performed in April 2009, but no prominent coronal structures were detectable due to low solar activity
* Tests of the narrow-band filters showed that they require heating to tune the passband to the green line wavelength
	* The filter characteristics (transmission, passband width, and central wavelength) vary slightly with radial distance
* Test observations confirmed the good optical and photometric quality of the data, with low noise levels and instrumental scattered light
	* The setup is ready to measure prominent active region coronal loops when they appear under favorable conditions
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs
	• Vertices with enough chips "fire" one chip to each neighbor simultaneously
	• The game has a finite number of positions that eventually repeat
	• It has connections to number theory, algebra, combinatorics, and physics
	• It can simulate logic gates and solve computational problems
• Lemmas are established bounding the number of chips and defining complement positions
	• In games with nontrivial period, vertices have at most 2n-1 chips
	• Confined positions have vertices with chips in a specific range
	• The complement of a confined position has the same firing behavior
	• A period occurs iff each vertex has fired the same number of times
• For complete bipartite graphs, the only possible periods are 1, 2, t, or 2t
	• t is the number of vertices on the side with fewer vertices
	• Lemmas relate the number of times vertices on each side have fired
	• Specific initial positions are constructed with periods t and 2t
	• Combined with previous results, this characterizes all possible periods
• For complete k-partite graphs, positions with period k(t-1)+1 are constructed
	• t ranges from 1 to the number of vertices in the smallest part
	• Each vertex fires when it has at least as many chips as its degree
	• After k(t-1)+1 steps, each vertex has fired exactly once
	• This shows periods from k to the number of vertices are achievable
• Further research directions are proposed
	• Proving the period is at most the number of vertices for certain graphs
	• Relating period lengths to attributes like activity or subcycle lengths
	• Studying transient lengths and reduced parallel chip-firing games
	• Applying the game to model real-world phenomena like sandpiles
</summary>

<summary>

• Fan defined a graph associated to multiple points of a line arrangement and proved results about the projective fundamental group

• The paper aims to study which line arrangements have a fundamental group with a conjugation-free geometric presentation

	• The main result is that arrangements whose graph is a disjoint union of cycles with no line having more than two multiple points have a conjugation-free geometric presentation
• The exact group structure is given for an arrangement whose graph is a triangle with all multiple points of multiplicity 3
	• It is a semidirect product of free groups
	• This family of arrangements is broader than the family of nice or simple arrangements where the lattice determines the fundamental group
	• The conjugation-free geometric presentations are complemented positive presentations in the sense of Dehornoy
• The Moishezon-Teicher algorithm and van Kampen theorem are used to compute fundamental groups

Here is a summary of the text using 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• Organic molecular crystals are promising for nanoscale devices, but the electronic structure of the organic-inorganic interface needs to be understood
	• Charge transfer between the organic and inorganic components is crucial
	• Image charge effects alter the addition and removal energies of charge carriers
	• Density functional theory (DFT) has limitations in describing these effects
	• Constrained DFT (CDFT) is a more efficient alternative to many-body approaches like GW
• CDFT is used to study a benzene molecule adsorbed on graphene in various configurations
	• CDFT calculates charge transfer energies by constraining electrons to molecule or substrate
	• The molecule-substrate distance and size of the graphene unit cell affect the results
	• Converged charge transfer energies are obtained for sufficiently large unit cells
	• The HOMO-LUMO gap of benzene on graphene approaches the gas phase value at large distances
• Structural defects in graphene, like Stone-Wales defects, have little effect on charge transfer energies
	• The defect does not significantly alter the graphene density of states near the Fermi level
	• The image charge distribution is not strongly affected by the presence of the defect
	• Doping graphene also has a minor effect on the charge transfer energies
• The presence of neighboring benzene molecules reduces the charge transfer energies
	• Induced charge dipoles in nearby molecules lower the electrostatic potential
	• The effect is more pronounced for the molecule than the graphene substrate
	• The reduction in HOMO-LUMO gap is similar regardless of the exact positions of other molecules
• The CDFT results agree well with a classical electrostatic model accounting for graphene's dielectric response
	• The model treats the transferred electron as a point charge and graphene as a polarizable sheet
	• Non-planar distribution of the image charge is included via an effective height parameter
	• The level renormalization on graphene differs from that on a perfect metal due to screening
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 3 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* The authors studied critical Casimir forces (CCFs) between two spherical colloids immersed in a near-critical binary liquid mixture near a substrate
	* CCFs are characterized by universal scaling functions that depend on boundary conditions, geometry, and thermodynamic state
	* Mean-field theory and finite element methods were used to calculate order parameter profiles and CCFs
	* Both normal and lateral CCFs were analyzed for various boundary conditions, distances, and temperatures
	* Many-body effects were quantified by subtracting pairwise colloid-colloid and colloid-substrate forces from the total force
* Results were compared to quantum-electrodynamic Casimir interactions and van der Waals forces
	* Lateral many-body CCFs are always attractive regardless of boundary conditions, unlike in the quantum case
	* Many-body contributions to normal CCFs decay slower with distance than for van der Waals forces between atoms near a surface
	* Many-body van der Waals forces are repulsive while many-body CCFs are attractive
	* For vertically-aligned colloids, many-body normal CCFs depend on the boundary conditions
* The preferred arrangement of the colloids depends on boundary conditions
	* For symmetric boundary conditions, colloids tend to aggregate laterally and form a monolayer on the substrate
	* For asymmetric boundary conditions, colloids tend to aggregate vertically and form 3D clusters
	* These tendencies are enhanced near the critical point
	* No completely stable configuration was found - there is always a nonzero force in the normal or lateral direction
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* MOPED is an algorithm for compressing data and speeding up likelihood function evaluation
	* It is particularly useful when the noise covariance matrix depends on model parameters
	* It compresses N data points into m values, one for each model parameter
	* It can provide orders of magnitude speed improvement in some cases
* MOPED has limitations and does not always accurately represent the likelihood function
	* It only guarantees maintaining the Fisher matrix at a chosen point
	* Multimodal and some degenerate distributions can be problematic
	* The authors demonstrate cases where MOPED fails to capture the true likelihood
* The validity of MOPED's likelihood representation depends on the intersections of hyper-surfaces where compressed values equal those at the true peak
	* A single intersection indicates MOPED is reliable
	* Multiple intersections mean MOPED may create erroneous peaks
	* Original likelihood must be checked to determine if multiple peaks are real or artifacts
* Potential solutions to MOPED's limitations are presented
	* Comparing original likelihoods of MOPED peak values can identify true peaks
	* Averaging log-likelihoods across multiple fiducial models maintains true peaks
	* However, this can significantly increase the SNR threshold for signal recovery
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 6 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* The cosmological constant problem (CCP) is a major puzzle in particle physics
	* The vacuum energy density can be the cosmological constant, with various sources such as zero point energy and potential energies from symmetry breaking
	* The vacuum energy density can receive large radiative corrections including a cutoff scale
* The experimental value of the cosmological constant is estimated to be very small, around 10^-47 GeV^4
	* This is much smaller than theoretical estimates of the vacuum energy density
	* The existence of this small "dark energy density" is a mystery not explained by current theories
* The authors suggest that a dominant part of dark energy could originate from gravitational corrections of vacuum energy
	* They assume that classical gravitational fields do not couple effectively to a large portion of the vacuum energy
	* External gravitons are conjectured to couple to gravitational corrections of vacuum energy involving internal gravitons
* The authors propose that physics around the TeV scale could be relevant to the dark energy of the universe
	* If the zero point energy of a scalar field dominates the vacuum energy, it could be a dark matter candidate
	* Superpartners appearing around the TeV scale could also contribute to the vacuum energy
* The evolution of the dark energy density is studied, assuming it varies logarithmically with the temperature of the universe
	* This evolution is described by a van der Waals type equation of state
	* The authors discuss possibilities for physics beyond the TeV scale, such as a cancellation mechanism or the existence of another type of graviton
* The authors conclude that solving the CCP may require a more fundamental theory of gravity
	* They suggest that a new ingredient or novel formalism may be needed
	* Understanding the relationship between classical and quantum gravitational fields could provide important insights
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 4 bullet points and 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* The rotation curves (RCs) of dwarf galaxies can be used to investigate the nature of dark matter (DM) and test cold dark matter (CDM) models
	* The Orion dwarf galaxy is an ideal candidate for this analysis due to its extended HI disk and reliable measurements of gas kinematics
	* Previous studies have shown that dwarf galaxy RCs are better fitted by cored DM profiles than cuspy profiles predicted by CDM simulations
	* MOND (Modified Newtonian Dynamics) has been successful in reproducing RCs of spiral galaxies without DM, but some cases of tension exist
* The stellar and gas components of the Orion dwarf were modeled using near-infrared photometry and HI observations
	* The stellar surface brightness profile is well-fitted by an exponential disk with no prominent bulge
	* The HI disk shows well-ordered rotation with some non-circular motions in the inner regions
	* The RC was derived using a tilted-ring model and corrected for asymmetric drift
* Mass modeling of the Orion dwarf was performed using both cored and cuspy DM halo profiles
	* The cored halo (URCH profile) provides an excellent fit to the observed RC
	* The cuspy halo (NFW profile) overestimates the circular velocity at galactocentric radii r > 2 kpc
	* MOND fails to reproduce the observed RC unless the galaxy distance is increased by a factor of 1.9
* The Orion dwarf is a representative case of a dwarf galaxy with a steep inner RC that flattens at the edge of the gas disk, implying the presence of large amounts of DM
	* Baryons alone cannot account for the observed kinematics and are only a minor mass component at all galactic radii
	* The inability of cuspy DM profiles to reproduce the observed kinematics is well-known in similar dwarf galaxies
	* Further observations, particularly a direct distance measurement, would be valuable for testing MOND in this system
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
* Transverse spin fluctuations are important low-energy excitations in magnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry
	* They significantly reduce the zero-temperature AF order parameter and Néel temperature
* A new method is described for evaluating transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections in the AF ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model
	* The method is based on magnon mode energies and spectral functions obtained in the random phase approximation (RPA)
* The method is illustrated for the pure Hubbard model in 2D and 3D, spin vacancies in the strong coupling limit in 2D, and low-U impurities in 2D
	* Results properly interpolate between weak and strong coupling limits, approaching spin-wave theory results as U/t → ∞
* For the spin vacancy problem, the quantum spin-fluctuation correction is sharply enhanced with increasing vacancy concentration
	* The AF order parameter vanishes near the percolation threshold due to spin fluctuations
* For the low-U impurity model, the spin-fluctuation correction is suppressed on average by the impurities
	* However, the correction is enhanced locally at the low-U impurity sites
* The local enhancement is due to increased magnon amplitude on the more strongly coupled impurity sites
	* The overall decrease is due to stiffening of the low-energy magnon spectrum from the increased average spin coupling
* The highest magnon energy is substantially reduced compared to the localized spin picture
	* This shows the compression effect of the low charge gap on the magnon spectrum
* The method allows for exact treatment of defects at the RPA level using numerical diagonalization for finite lattices with finite-size scaling
	* It can be readily extended to other situations involving defects in antiferromagnets
</summary>

Here is a summary of the text using 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:

<summary>
• Quantum communication technologies require quantum-enabled infrastructure
	• Quantum networks contain components like quantum memories, repeaters, and channels
	• Devices must operate in a strictly quantum way and not as measure-and-prepare channels
• Quantum throughput measures how well a channel preserves quantum correlations
	• Prepare-and-measure scenario used to test quantum throughput, bypassing need for entangled states
	• Entanglement of the output state compared to input to determine quantum throughput
• Method estimates most significant 2D subspace of output states using homodyne measurements
	• Subspace parameters estimated from means and variances of quadrature measurements
	• Projection of full state onto subspace used to bound entanglement
• Entanglement minimized over compatible forms of projected state subject to constraints
	• Semidefinite programming used to find minimal entanglement
	• Simplifications and relaxations made to constraints to enable convex optimization
